body:
Adds descriptive names for each packet and changes to allow using the name as an alternative to state/number. Not complete yet (can squash later, etc.) but I wanted to get your feedback for developing further, specifically:

- is this a worthwhile feature? I think so, makes it easier to use the API without knowing intricate specifics of the protocol, for example from mineflayer:


    `bot.client.on(0x38, function(packet) {`


would have to change to "0x26" for the 1.7 update, trading one "magic number" for another. But with this PR, you can simply write:

      bot.client.on('map_chunk_bulk', function(packet) {

and the code is much more descriptive and maintainable. node-minecraft-protocol already decodes field names, so I'd say decoding packet names is well within the scope of this module. Also it mitigates the complexity of having to listen on a stringified array "[state, id]", since the names are unique across all protocol states — the name infers both the state and id.

- Are the names themselves alright? They are almost straight from http://wiki.vg/Protocol (with a few changes for uniqueness), but maybe could use some refinement

- lib/client.js setSocket() now emits up to 4 events per packet: packetName, [state,id], id, 'packet' - is this too much?

- Is it a good idea to pass the name as a string literal, having the function translate to an id? Could instead have an object with keys of names, values state and id, but then mistyping a packet name would pass 'undefined' to the function, so I'm not sure that's a better approach.

- How about the data structures in lib/protocol.js? I added packetIDs, packetStates, packetNames, in addition to the existing 'packets' object which maps to the fields. Could be worthwhile to merge packetIDs and packets so the field names and packet names are defined together, but I wasn't sure of the best way to do this. 

- Listening/sending by state/id still works as before

- Updated the examples to demonstrate this new API (plus a few minor unrelated changes: client_chat.js offline mode, fix the server.js example to send the given message, and remove unsupported '§e' styling).

comment_data.body:
I think I like this idea. I've toyed with it before but I never came around to actually coding it up.

> lib/client.js setSocket() now emits up to 4 events per packet: packetName, [state,id], id, 'packet' - is this too much?

I don't think it would be too much. @mappum added a benchmark script; we should be able to use this to find out empirically if there is a speed penalty. If anything, I would want to remove [state, id] from the list; if you didn't want to use the packet name you could check the state with an if statement.

> Is it a good idea to pass the name as a string literal, having the function translate to an id? 

I'd like to have a single structure that contains all the data for all packets in one place. Once, at runtime, when the module is required, we can iterate over the structure and create an index from packet name to packet. At this time we can perform sanity checks to make sure no duplicate names exist and all packets have names. Looks like you hinted at this in your next bullet point.

:+1: I love this (although I love hex values, they do hold a lot less meaning to us humans XD). If you want to reduce events, I recently had an idea : override the .on() to transform the [state, packetId] and packetId (and now potentially the special-names) into a string manually. So only one emit, but multiple "on" types.

>  If you want to reduce events, I recently had an idea : override the .on() to transform the [state, packetId] and packetId (and now potentially the special-names) into a string manually

I'm not necessarily against this, but I am also not convinced it would change the execution speed in any significant way. I would ask that you benchmark it to prove that it really makes that much of a difference.

Emitting events with no listeners should be pretty negligible in terms of
performance. However, doing things like repeatedly creating arrays (e.g.
your [state, packetId]) will cause slowdowns if you are doing it enough per
second. The total time to create them and eventually clean them up in the
GC is surpisingly significant in high quantities. (The benchmark shouldn't
pick up on the GC unless you run it with more iterations though).

BTW, the benchmark currently doesn't have a lot of test packets, you might
want to edit it to be a bit more accurate.
On Jan 7, 2014 12:01 PM, "Andrew Kelley" <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> If you want to reduce events, I recently had an idea : override the .on()
> to transform the [state, packetId] and packetId (and now potentially the
> special-names) into a string manually
>
> I'm not necessarily against this, but I am also not convinced it would
> change the execution speed in any significant way. I would ask that you
> benchmark it to prove that it really makes that much of a difference.
>
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub<https://github.com/superjoe30/node-minecraft-protocol/pull/70#issuecomment-31773496>
> .
>

That's what I was thinking @mappum . About the benchmark, I've been thinking about adding the potentially "bad" packets (rare array types, map chunk bulk, etc...) and wrapping it in a mocha "describe"/"it" so we can easily turn it off when running the unit tests.

Updated with latest commits:

> If anything, I would want to remove [state, id] from the list; 

Removed this event, though I have no strong opinion either way. Haven't benchmarked to measure any performance difference, though it does seem to result in a slightly cleaner API. As you can always listen for the state and then packet id events, like you said. But it wasn't clear to me how to convert a `client.once([state, packetId])` listener (test/test.js:testPacket uses this pattern).

> single structure that contains all the data for all packets in one place

Merged into a single data structure, `packets`. When the module is loaded, lookup tables are populated for packet fields, names, ids, and states. Also added some basic sanity checks for duplicate/missing values.

I've been working on node-minecraft-protocol a bit lately. Looked at this again, and while I still aprove of the idea, I think for the sake of consistency, we should use the same naming scheme as ProtocolLib, which is probably the most widely used minecraft protocol library. 

http://aadnk.github.io/ProtocolLib/Javadoc/com/comphenix/protocol/PacketType.html under Handshake, Login, Play and Status.
We could use our own naming convention (camelCase instead of all-caps with underscore), but keeping the names consistent would make updating to new protocol versions a lot easier, especially since wiki.vg names aren't set in stones, whereas those in protocollib are unlikely to change.

@roblabla You have commit access and I think that everyone trusts you to make good decisions. Other people, myself included, seem to not have much time to look at stuff right now. In my opinion, you should feel free to start merging your own pull requests and generally start carrying this project forward. Maybe for code changes make a pull request, give it 24 hours for anyone to comment on, and then merge it.

If you tell me your npm username I will add you to the npm owner list so that you can make releases too.

@roblabla :+1: to switching to ProtocolLib packet names, sounds like a good idea to me for better stability. Unfortunately I haven't had much time to work on this lately either, if you want to merge and make these changes feel free =)

Currently in the process of writing a small tool that, given a minecraft.jar (obfuscated or not), will output the JSON of the protocol specification. I just spent some time trying implementing latest snapshot protocol, and it bugged me how the changes to the JSON could have easily been automated.

Once that's done, I'll be pulling your changes to my fork, update the names, and create a new PR.
#77 is the continuation of this, using ProtocolLib packet name.

title: Allow sending and listening for packets by "name" instead of number
